Package net.openhft.chronicle.network

Enum TCPRegistry

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.lang.Enum<TCPRegistry>
      • net.openhft.chronicle.network.TCPRegistry
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<TCPRegistry>
    public enum TCPRegistry
extends Enum<TCPRegistry>
    The TCPRegistry allows you to either provide a true host and port for example "localhost:8080" or if you would rather let the application allocate you a free port at random, you can just provide a text reference to the port, for example "host.port", you can provide any text you want, it will always be taken as a reference, that is unless its correctly formed like "<hostname>:<port>‚Äù, then it will use the exact host and port you provide. For listen addresses, if hostname is empty or * then all local addresses will be listened on.

    The reason we offer this functionality is quite often in unit tests you wish to start a test via loopback, followed often by another test via loopback, if the first test does not shut down correctly it can impact on the second test. Giving each test a unique port is one solution, but then managing those ports can become a problem in its self. So we created the TCPRegistry which manages those ports for you, when you come to clean up at the end of each test, all you have to do it call TCPRegistry.reset() and it will ensure that any remaining ports that are open will be closed.
